figureCitation.captionText: FIGURE 37. Nebrioporus ressli: a) habitus, male from north-western Iran; b) idem, female; c) idem, male from Uzbekistan; d) idem, female; e) male right hind tarsus, dorsal view (specimen from north-western Iran); f) lateral view of male left fore claws, specimen from Uzbekistan; g) idem, specimen from north-western Iran; h) left paramere; i) median lobe of aedeagus, dorsal and lateral view.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 58. Habitus photograph of
Nebrioporus laeviventris
(female).

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. TL 4.6–5.5 mm ; MW 2.3–2.7 mm . Oblong-oval, slightly convex. Dorsal colouration dark yellow with brown patterns not very extended on elytra.
Head yellow, without dark markings. Mouthparts reddish, with last article of maxillary palpi darkened; antennae testaceous with last 5-6 articles widely darkened, especially last ones. Genae black.

Pronotum rather transverse, maximum width near half of its length. Sides rounded, bordered, posterior angles rahter rounded. Posterior side slightly sinuate, angle between pronotum and elytra slightly developed.
Elytra oblong-oval, with maximum width near middle, covered by fine yellow pubescence. Longitudinal rows of punctures hardly visible. Subapical spines not or hardly visible.

Underside black, prosternal process and distal portion of metacoxal process and third sternite reddish. Surface covered by dense and finely impressed punctuation. Reticulation hardly visible between punctures. Sternites with apical comb of small setae. Epipleuron yellow.
Legs dark, brownish-yellow, tarsi slightly darkened. Metatibiae with long row of setigerous punctures.

Male: Subapical spines on elytra almost invisible. Protarsi dilated. Anterior claws ( Fig. 37e–g ) straight and acuminate: outer twice or three times as long as inner. Genitals ( Fig. 37h,i ) as in
N. lanceolatus
.
Female: Posterior angles and lateral sides of pronotum slightly more rounded. Subapical spines on elytra more visible. Elytral apex slightly produced.

Distribution ( Fig. 51 ). This species, considered endemic to Northern Iran , has been recently recorded also for Afghanistan ( Hajek & Fery 2004 ); here it is recorded for the first time for eastern Turkmenistan , eastern Uzbekistan , and western Tajikistan . It seems associated with mountainous areas, but at lower altitude (max 700 m a.s.l. in Afghanistan ).
